In this proof, notice that:
\begin{itemize}
\item ``Alice is married'' is a \textit{hypothesis}.
\item The \textit{conclusion} is that a married person looks at an unmarried person.
\item This \textit{style} of proof is called \textbf{proof by exhaustion}, because we have considered all possible cases: Bob is married, and Bob is not married.
\item This proof contains logic only. There is no calculation.
\end{itemize}

Mathematical proof is important:
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{to convince} - Proofs help you decide if and why a statement is true or false. This is important when the result seems strange.
\item \textbf{to understand} - Proofs help you understand how and why all the different assumptions play a part in the result.
\item \textbf{to communicate} - Mathematicians use proofs to communicate and debate ideas with each other.
\item \textbf{to organise} - Proofs help you organise your thoughts.
\item \textbf{to discover new mathematics} - By carefully examining each step of a proof, mathematicians discover new mathematics.
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\item State what you are proving. Make it clear when you have reached your conclusion.
\item Include enough detail to make your proof easy to check.
\item Your proof should be written in good English, including simple, complete, correct sentences.
\item Present your calculations on the page in a manner which makes them easy to follow. Use your layout to clearly separate the parts or different cases considered in your proof.
\item Use diagrams when appropriate to give a visual representation of the situation.
\item It is often useful to use examples when exploring a problem. However, a single example is usually not sufficient to complete a proof.
\item Check to see where you have used each hypothesis. If you have not used a particular hypothesis then either:
  \begin{itemize}
  \item you did not need it, or
  \item your proof should have made use of it, and is incorrect!
  \end{itemize}
\item Do not expect to write a complete proof the first time. Expect to use rough working first, and then write a neat version.
\end{itemize}

Mathematical language uses \textbf{logical connectives} to link mathematical statements together:

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textit{Connective} & \textit{Symbol} & \textit{Formal name} \\
\hline
and & $\wedge$ & conjunction \\
or & $\vee$ & disjunction \\
not & $\neg$ & negation \\
if .... then .... & $\Rightarrow$ & implication \\
if, and only if & $\Leftrightarrow$ & equivalence \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

We can illustrate the use of these connectives using \textit{variables} such as $A$, $B$, $C$, ....

For example, $(A \wedge B) \Rightarrow C$ means ``$A$ and $B$ implies $C$''. The two arguments $(A \wedge B)$ and $C$ are connected by the connective $\Rightarrow$. The argument $(A \wedge B)$ is itself made up of arguments $A$ and $B$, connected by the connective $\wedge$. It is therefore helpful to think of statements as mathematical trees, connected by the logical connectives.

The negation of a variable $A$ is its opposite. If $A$ is true then $\neg A$ is false, and vice versa.

For example:
\begin{itemize}
\item the negation of ``Today is Wednesday'' is ``Today is not Wednesday''
\item if we know $x \in \mathbb{Z}$, the negation of ``$x$ is an even integer'' is ``$x$ is an odd integer''
\item if we know $x \in \mathbb{R}$, the negation of ``$x$ is an even integer'' is ``$x$ is not an even integer'', since $x$ might be an odd integer, or it might also be a non-integer.
\end{itemize}

Implications commonly arise when we deduce one thing from another.

For the implication $A \Rightarrow B$, we start with the statement $A$, and from it we deduce the statement $B$. The statement $A$ is called the \textbf{hypothesis}, and $B$ is called the \textbf{conclusion}.

In English there are many words we can use to show an implication.

For example: $A \begin{cases} \text{implies} \\ \text{so} \\ \text{hence} \\ \text{thus} \\ \text{therefore} \end{cases} B.$

We use $\therefore$ to mean ``therefore''.

The \textbf{converse} of the implication $A \Rightarrow B$ is the statement $B \Rightarrow A$.

It is important to recognise that while the implication $A \Rightarrow B$ may be true, its converse may not be true.

For example, the statement ``If $x = 2$ then $x^2 = 4$'' is true. However, its converse ``If $x^2 = 4$ then $x = 2$'' is false, since $x$ may be $-2$.

Two statements $A$ and $B$ are \textbf{equivalent} if both $A \Rightarrow B$ \textit{and} $B \Rightarrow A$. In this case we can say $A$ is true if and only if $B$ is true.

For example, the statement ``If $x = -2$ or $2$, then $x^2 = 4$'' is true. The statement ``If $x^2 = 4$ then $x = -2$ or $2$'' is also true. Therefore, $x = -2$ or $2 \Leftrightarrow x^2 = 4$.

Throughout the course already, we have used algebra to show different results. In cases where we are given some information (the hypothesis) and are asked to prove something, we use a chain of implications. This is called \textbf{proof by deduction}.

Proof by deduction is called a \textbf{direct proof} because we start with the hypothesis and work forward towards the conclusion.

We have mostly used the therefore symbol ``$\therefore$'' to indicate our implications, but we could have also used the implication symbol ``$\Rightarrow$''.

Since these arguments only need to go from the starting information to the conclusion, we also call this type of proof a ``left-to-right'' proof.

In proof by deduction, we were only concerned with moving in one direction.

This means that if we want to show that two statements $A$ and $B$ are \textit{equivalent}, then we would need to prove both $A \Rightarrow B$ and $B \Rightarrow A$ separately.

However, if we can construct an argument so that each deductive step is an equivalence, then we will prove $A \Rightarrow B$ and $B \Rightarrow A$ at the same time.

For example, to deduce the solutions of $(x+1)^3 = x^3 + 1$ we can write the following series of equivalent statements:

$(x + 1)^3 = x^3 + 1$
$\Leftrightarrow x^3 + 3x^2 + 3x + 1 = x^3 + 1$
$\Leftrightarrow 3x^2 + 3x = 0$
$\Leftrightarrow 3x(x + 1) = 0$
$\Leftrightarrow x = 0$ or $x = -1$

Reasoning by equivalence is stronger than deduction because the converse must also be true in every step.

This chain of reasoning relies on the facts that:
\begin{itemize}
\item two equations are equivalent if they have precisely the same solutions
\item two functions $p(x)$ and $q(x)$ are equivalent if $p(x) = q(x)$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$.
\end{itemize}

There are some other operations which maintain equivalence, for example some of the rules of logarithms with positive terms.

However, squaring or taking square roots of both sides of an equation does not maintain equivalence!

Given $a^2 = b^2$, taking the square root of both sides gives $a = b$. However, in doing this we have ignored the possibility that $a = -b$.

Instead, we use the difference between two squares result as follows:

$a^2 = b^2$
$\Leftrightarrow a^2 - b^2 = 0$
$\Leftrightarrow (a - b)(a + b) = 0$ \quad \{difference between two squares\}
$\Leftrightarrow a - b = 0$ or $a + b = 0$ \quad \{null factor law\}
$\Leftrightarrow a = b$ or $a = -b$
$\Leftrightarrow a = \pm b$

\textbf{Example 2}

Find the smallest positive integer $a$ for which $x^2 + (a - 2)x + a = 0$ has real solutions.

questions.problem_latex: Find the smallest positive integer $a$ for which $x^2 + (a - 2)x + a = 0$ has real solutions.
questions.answer_latex:
$x^2 + (a - 2)x + a = 0$
$\Leftrightarrow \left(x + \frac{a-2}{2}\right)^2 - \left(\frac{a-2}{2}\right)^2 + a = 0$ \quad \{completing the square\}
$\Leftrightarrow \left(x + \frac{a-2}{2}\right)^2 = \frac{(a-2)^2}{4} - a$

The equation has real solutions if and only if
$\frac{(a-2)^2}{4} - a \geqslant 0$
$\Leftrightarrow (a-2)^2 - 4a \geqslant 0$
$\Leftrightarrow a^2 - 8a + 4 \geqslant 0$
$\Leftrightarrow (a-4)^2 - 16 + 4 \geqslant 0$
$\Leftrightarrow (a-4)^2 \geqslant 12$
$\Leftrightarrow a - 4 \geqslant \sqrt{12}$ or $a - 4 \leqslant -\sqrt{12}$
$\Leftrightarrow a \geqslant 4 + \sqrt{12} \approx 7.46$ or $a \leqslant 4 - \sqrt{12} \approx 0.536$

$\therefore$ the smallest positive integer $a$ for which the equation has real solutions is $a = 8$.

\textbf{Example 3}

Prove that $0.\overline{13} \in \mathbb{Q}$.

questions.problem_latex: Prove that $0.\overline{13} \in \mathbb{Q}$.
questions.answer_latex:
Let $x = 0.\overline{13} = 0.1313131313....$
$\Rightarrow 100x = 13.13131313....$
$\Rightarrow 100x = 13 + x$
$\Rightarrow 99x = 13$
$\Rightarrow x = \frac{13}{99}$
$\Rightarrow x \in \mathbb{Q}$
$\Rightarrow 0.\overline{13} \in \mathbb{Q}$

\textbf{Example 4}

Prove that the sum of any two rational numbers is also a rational number.

questions.problem_latex: Prove that the sum of any two rational numbers is also a rational number.
questions.answer_latex:
\textbf{Proof:}
Let $x$ and $y$ be two rational numbers.
By definition, there exists $p, q \in \mathbb{Z}$, $q \neq 0$ so that $x = \frac{p}{q}$.
By definition, there exists $r, s \in \mathbb{Z}$, $s \neq 0$ so that $y = \frac{r}{s}$.

So, $x + y = \frac{p}{q} + \frac{r}{s} = \frac{ps + rq}{qs}$

Since $p, q, r, s$ are all integers, $ps + rq$ is an integer which we call $P$.
Since $q, s$ are non-zero integers, $qs$ is a non-zero integer which we call $Q$.
$\therefore x + y = \frac{ps + rq}{qs} = \frac{P}{Q}$ where $P, Q \in \mathbb{Z}$, $Q \neq 0$
$\therefore$ by definition, $x + y$ is a rational number.

An \textbf{axiom} is a statement that is taken to always be true. Axioms form the foundation for proofs of all results and theorems in mathematics.

For example, these are the axioms for addition and multiplication on the real numbers:

\textit{Axiom 1:} Associativity: $a + (b + c) = (a + b) + c$ and $a \times (b \times c) = (a \times b) \times c$

\textit{Axiom 2:} Commutativity: $a + b = b + a$ and $a \times b = b \times a$

\textit{Axiom 3:} Distributivity: $a \times (b + c) = a \times b + a \times c$

\textit{Axiom 4:} Additive identity: $a + 0 = a$ and Multiplicative identity: $a \times 1 = a$

\textit{Axiom 5:} Additive inverse: $a + (-a) = 0$ and Multiplicative inverse: $a \times a^{-1} = 1$.

Using only these axioms, we can prove that $0 \times x = x \times 0 = 0$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$.

\textbf{Example 5}

Given that $n^5 - n = (n-1)n(n+1)(n^2+1)$, prove that $n^5 - n$ is divisible by 5 for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}$.

questions.problem_latex: Given that $n^5 - n = (n-1)n(n+1)(n^2+1)$, prove that $n^5 - n$ is divisible by 5 for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}$.
questions.answer_latex:
\textbf{Proof by exhaustion:}
If we divide $n$ by 5 then the remainder will be 0, 1, 2, 3, or 4. Hence every integer can be written in one of the forms $5k$, $5k+1$, $5k+2$, $5k+3$, or $5k+4$, for some $k \in \mathbb{Z}$.

Let $N = n^5 - n = (n-1)n(n+1)(n^2+1)$.

If $n = 5k$ then the factor $n$ is divisible by 5, and so $N$ is divisible by 5.

If $n = 5k + 1$ then the factor $(n - 1) = 5k$ is divisible by 5, so $N$ is divisible by 5.

If $n = 5k + 2$ then the factor $(n^2 + 1) = (5k + 2)^2 + 1$
$= 25k^2 + 20k + 5$
$= 5(5k^2 + 4k + 1)$
which is divisible by 5, so $N$ is divisible by 5.

If $n = 5k + 3$ then the factor $(n^2 + 1) = (5k + 3)^2 + 1$
$= 25k^2 + 30k + 10$
$= 5(5k^2 + 6k + 2)$
which is divisible by 5, so $N$ is divisible by 5.

If $n = 5k + 4$ then the factor $(n + 1) = 5(k + 1)$ which is divisible by 5, so $N$ is divisible by 5.

In all cases, $N$ is divisible by 5, so $n^5 - n$ is divisible by 5 for all $n \in \mathbb{Z}$.

items.content_latex: Experimental evidence is very convincing, and scientific research relies on experimental evidence. However, in mathematics we do not consider experimental evidence to be sufficient to constitute a \textit{proof}. The reason for this is that one single \textbf{counter example} which shows a general statement to be false, is sufficient to \textit{disprove} the statement.

The values of $n^2 - n + 41$ for some values of $n \in \mathbb{N}$ are shown in the table alongside. We observe that all of these values are primes, so we conjecture that:

Find an example which proves this conjecture is false.

questions.problem_latex: Find an example which proves this conjecture is false.
questions.answer_latex:
For $n = 41$, we have $n^2 - n + 41 = 41^2 - 41 + 41 = 41^2$ which is not prime.
$\therefore$ the conjecture is false.
